body.p: “For there is Cheney’s abele “,” which stands just south of a large elm. It grows wholly southward “,” and in form is just half a tree. So with the tupelos under the Hill shore “,” east of Fair Haven Pond. They terminate abruptly like a bull’s horn “,” having no upward leading shoot “,” and bend off over the water “,” –are singularly one-sided. In short “,” trees appear to grow regularly because the sky and diffusion of light are commonly regular.”
PE 14, pg. 443/ 9 November 1858-7 April 1859 / NNPM MA 1302:34 / T vol. # XXVIII / PDF # XVII / JXI
